fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition
When a change is made in a SubTree, an indication is shown in {{File Status}}.
There is no indication at the moment next to the SubTree name, in the {{SubTrees}} list.

 !Screen Shot 2016-01-25 at 13.56.50.png|thumbnail! 

The user cannot see that changes have been made in a SubTree, unless he opens {{File Status}} View.

h3. Suggested Solution

When changes are made in a SubTree, show an indication next to the SubTree name, in the SubTrees list.
fields.summary: As a user I want to see an indication that a SubTree has been modified in SourceTree, next to the SubTree name

fields.description:
It seems that in current version of SourceTree this functionality doesn't work again.

Original message:
My global .gitconfig file contains lines similar to this:

[commit]
	template = /Users/kate.ebneter/.git_template.txt

When using command-line git, this causes the commit message to be populated with the contents of .git_template.txt. However, when committing via SourceTree, I get a blank commit message. It would be really nice if SourceTree honored this git setting.
fields.summary: SourceTree doesn't honor the commit.template setting in .gitconfig

fields.description: Seems to be a limit on the # of stashes that can be shown in ST.  The limit seems to be somewhere around 100 - once you cross the threshold, stash data just disappears and is not displayed.
fields.summary: Stash data is not displayed when there are a large # stashes in a repo.

fields.description: f you are working on a repo that has many commits - more than 50 (estimate). If new commits are loaded automatically in the bg while you are scrolling through, or selecting commits below the first 20 or so - the list of the files modified by the commit you have selected will not load.  This is a follow up issue to https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/SRCTREE-3348.
fields.summary: List of the files modified by the commit you have selected will not load when new commits are loaded.

fields.description: If you are working on a repo that has many commits - more than 50 (estimate).  If new commits are loaded automatically in the bg while you are scrolling through, or selecting commits below the first 20 or so - your selection in the list will reset, and you will lose your place.  See https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/SRCTREE-3349 for a follow up issue.
fields.summary: Selection in commit list is reset when new commits are loaded

fields.description: Say I want to view commit a1b2c3d of the repo ssh://server/git/repo.git locally cloned at /home/user/work/repo1, I'd ideally like to be able open a URL like rev://server/git/repo.git/commit/a1b2c3d and have Sourcetree display that commit from one of (first found?) locally cloned workspace that matches server/git/repo.git.
fields.summary: support a URL scheme to locally view commits

fields.description:
As a user I'd like to be able to monitor my pull requests from the SourceTree application.

Often when I have created a pull request on Bitbucket I loose track of it and miss important updates about it, only to discover it a couple of hours later with some comments and/or an approval or two. 

It would be very nice if I could see all pull requests I am mixed up in directly in the repository view in SourceTree, perhaps in the left hand side menu where branches, stashes etcetera are today. Preferably I can set it up to give me some nice notifications about progress and changes as well. 


Cheers!
fields.summary: Monitoring pull requests

fields.description:
The basic interface no longer works. Buttons appear double, they don't move to make room for other interface items, and so on:

 !Screen Shot 2016-01-19 at 3.58.06 PM.png|thumbnail! 

 !Screen Shot 2016-01-19 at 3.57.57 PM.png|thumbnail! 

Also, files in these file browsers are not listed properly, are not clickable, and so forth; thus I can't learn what files have changes, I can't stage them, and so on. The program is currently useless.
fields.summary: Interface unusable, buttons and popup menus show ghosts, etc.

fields.description:
Sourcetree should be updated to use one command "git checkout -b branchname" when creating a new local branch and the checkout branch option is selected.  

There is nowhere in SourceTree to create the branch based off local.
fields.summary: Update checkout, and/or create branch function to allow branch creation based off local.

fields.description:
When clicking the checkbox in "Unstaged files" pane, the item is added to "Staged files". That is fine. The problem is the Unstaged view is reset, seemingly randomly, so that one must scroll back to the same area of the list (I'm using a tree view) to select adjacent files. 

It should not require scrolling to get back the the view. It should work as it does in flat list view mode.
fields.summary: Unstaged files pane is not a stable view when in tree view

fields.description:
It would be useful to see chat the status is of the branches you have locally, if there is a pull request or if they are merged into the default branch.

I would suggest you implement this so that "M" (for merged) or "PR" (for open pull request) is visible right-aligned next to the branch name. This would make it easier for people that manage a lot of branches, each wil their own JIRA task, so that they can track which branches have been merged so they can delete them locally.

Optionally, I would like to see a notification of "Your branch [branch-name] has been merged into [another-branch]"
fields.summary: Add remote status to branches

fields.description:
Whenever HEAD is set to a historical commit of a branch and you filter the timeline view to show _'current branch only'_ or _'HEAD detached at xxxxxxx'_ the timeline view does not render and instead shows the error: {{'git log' failed with code 128:'fatal: bad revision '(HEAD detached at xxxxxxx)'}}, removing the _'current branch'_ filter allows the timeline view to render.

However {{git log}} works just fine on the command line.

fields.description:
h3. Summary
During an Interactive Rebase, we resolve a conflict using 'Theirs'. Then, we proceed to commit by clicking the {{Commit}} button from the toolbar.

A pop up appears informing us that the rebase is in progress. If we {{Continue Rebase}} the process never completes, the changes remain uncommitted and rebase is still in progress.

h3. Environment
SourceTree Mac 2.1

h3. Steps to Reproduce
Use the testrepo attached
# Right click commit 49de492
# Select {{Rebase children of 49de492 interactively}}
# Select {{OK}}
# Go to Working Copy
# Right click the file >> {{Resolve Conflicts}} >> {{Resolve Using 'Theirs'}} >> {{OK}}
# Select {{Commit}} from the toolbar
# Popup that shows up select {{Continue Rebase}}

h3. Expected Results

The changes should be committed and rebase should be continued.

h3. Actual Results

The pop up that appears after {{Continue Rebase}} shows a progress bar that never finishes.
 !Screen Shot 2016-01-08 at 15.56.41.png|thumbnail! 

If we click {{Cancel >> Close}}, another pop up titled {{Errors During Merge}} appears, which is empty.
 !Screen Shot 2016-01-08 at 15.56.53.png|thumbnail! 

If we close that, we see that the changes are not committed and rebase is still in progress.
 

h3. Workaround

If one clicks the {{Commit}} button at the bottom right of the SourceTree window instead, the changes are committed. Then, one can continue the rebase from the menu {{Actions >> Continue Rebase}}.
fields.summary: Clicking Commit from the toolbar after resolving a conflict during an interactive rebase does not complete

fields.description:
As it is now, SourceTree only allows the user to Stash All current changes.  It's kind of an all or nothing behavior.  However Git itself allows Stashing at the individual hunk level.  It would be an amazing feature if we could create a Stash the way we create Commits, by setting up the Staging Area with what we want and then capturing the Stash from the Staging Area.

REQUEST:
The ability to create a Stash consisting only from the changes that are in the Staging Area, similar to the way that we create a commit.

BEHAVIOR:
 1.  Add changes to the Staging Area as normal... hunks, lines, whatever.

2.  Select the Stash button.  See two options:
    2A:  An option to create a Stash out of ALL of your changes (original behavior)
    2B:  An option to create a Stash consisting of only the changes that are in the Staging Area.

3.  When you select option 2B, the Stash gets created, and previously staged changes no longer appear in the Working Directory.  Changes that were in the Working Directory, but not in the Staging Area still appear in the Working Directory as expected.

4. A Once you have a stash created, the stash would of course continue to apply as a whole stash, all or nothing.

REASON:
This would allow us to create more granular stashes which is very helpful in certain development scenarios.
fields.summary: Ability to Create Stash Consisting Only of Changes in Staging Area

fields.description:
When you apply a stash with SourceTree, the checkbox for "Delete after applying" always defaults to being checked. Since this is a destructive operation, it should default to something safer like being unchecked, remembering the last checkbox state, or be configurable in the Git settings panel of SourceTree.

Notes:
* Screenshots attached
* Also, it's possible that this should be applied for both Mac and Win versions of SourceTree, but I do not have a Windows machine to test if this is the case.
fields.summary: Apply stash dialog should not default to having "Delete after applying" checked

2) While adding local repository search would be faster as the folder will be selected by default

fields.description: A stacktrace forced the height to be larger and extended beyond my screen (screenshot attached). The dialog height should probably be set to the maximum of the screen.
fields.summary: Settings dialog extends beyond the screen

fields.description: `/usr/bin/python` is used when SourceTree uses the embedded Mercurial. SourceTree should probably query the user's $PATH.
fields.summary: Incorrect Python used for Mercurial

fields.description:
Steps to reproduce:

# Start SourceTree, wait for main window ("SourceTree" with a blue bar at top.
# Grab window with mouse, keep mouse pressed, move window around
# After a while (sometimes 5s, but often 30s -- 1min, time seems to be very intermittent), the window starts to move erratically ("jump around") and not completely follow mouse movements.

This seems to happen with the main window only. I've tried to force it with the repo windows, but I've not seen it there.

Feel free to let me know if I can help track this down in some way. I've never seen this behavior in any other OSX application, so I don't really know where to start looking.
fields.summary: Moving SourceTree main window becomes erratic

fields.description:
SourceTree crashes every time when trying to open a repository from repository browser or from the terminal.

Crashes still persists after clearing Sourcetree preferences.

Please find the log from the console attached.
fields.summary: Sourcetree Crashes when open a repository from terminal or from repository browser.

fields.description:
The “Resolve Conflicts > Resolve Using \{Mine|Theirs\}” commands in SourceTree do not behave as expected. Rather than resolving conflicts according to the selected side, it seems that the ENTIRE FILE is replaced by either “mine” or “theirs”.

As a user, I expect that the successfully auto-merged chunks remain intact (as they first do prior to conflict resolution). Instead, they are unexpectedly reverted.

Verifying this bug has been made more troublesome by the fact that SourceTree does not log in its command history panel what it's actually doing when I choose a resolve command.

The current behaviour renders the “Resolve Conflicts” command mostly useless (and indeed dangerous), making a manual treatment (by editing the text of the conflicted merge product) the only way to achieve the correct merge.
​
fields.summary: Resolve merge command blows away entire file, irrespective of conflicts

fields.description:
SourceTree keeps on crashing. 2.0.5.8 is no exception. Please remove all versions after 2.0.5.5 from being default upgrade/install versions, to help people avoid installing your crashing versions.

Latest version known to not crash frequently is 2.0.5.5. Download from: http://downloads.atlassian.com/software/sourcetree/SourceTree_2.0.5.5.dmg

Steps to reproduce one of my crashes:
# Start SourceTree
# Answer initial dialogues about license, etc (assuming a preference wipe)
# Click button "+New Repository"
# Select "Clone from URL"
# Click on highlighted text "remote account" --> Crash

There are also other steps that lead to crashes, and I'll try to narrow them down too.
fields.summary: SourceTree Crash

fields.description: If active for some hours or often when starting up, SourceTree crashes.
fields.summary: ST crashes on OS X 10.11 El Capitan

fields.description:

I even tried older installing older version 2.0.5.5 but same crash happens. I moved to latest, thinking it might be fixed.

fields.summary: SourceTree crash when clicking on remote branches

fields.description:
Replication:
# Create Git repo
# Add a file
# Add a symlink to the file
# Replace symlink with a regular file

Expected:
* SourceTree shows file as changed

Actual
* SourceTree does not show any changes for the file-that-used-to-be-a-symlink
* Command line `git status` shows it as `typechange: path/to/file`
fields.summary: SourceTree does not show "typechange" git changes

fields.description:
h3. Summary

When a user adds a Subtree with Local Relative Path a subfolder of an existing Subtree, then the second Subtree is added, but it is not visible in the Sidebar >> Subtrees section.

h3. Environment

SourceTree for Mac, reproduced with the latest version, 2.0.5.7. 
This feature is working well in SourceTree for Windows.

h3. Steps to Reproduce

# Open SourceTree in Mac.
# Open a Git repository.
# Right-click the sidebar and select Add/Link Subtree.
# Add a Subtree, with 'Local Relative Path' equal to dir1.
# Right-click the sidebar and select Add/Link Subtree.
# Add a second Subtree, with 'Local Relative Path' equal to dir1/dir2/dir3/dir4.

h3. Expected Results

The Subtrees section in the sidebar shows both Subtrees, as follows (screenshot from  SourceTree for Windows).

 !Screen Shot 2015-11-25 at 14.46.19.png|thumbnail! 

h3. Actual Results

The Subtrees section in the sidebar only shows the firstly added Subtree.

 !Screen Shot 2015-11-25 at 14.41.50.png|thumbnail! 

h3.Workaround

No workaround available.
fields.summary: Adding a Subtree in a subfolder of an existing Subtree, results in the 2nd Subtree being invisible in the 'Subtrees' section in the Sidebar

fields.summary: Sourcetree Crashing a few seconds after start

fields.description:
I was experiencing random crashes with 2.0.5.6 and was eventually directed to SRCTREE-3260.

I followed the advice to install 2.0.5.5, and things seemed to work fine.

When 2.0.5.7 came out, I installed it immediately, and saw no problems at first.

Eventually, I began experiencing crashes that seemed very similar to those in 2.0.5.6, but _much_ less often.

The bad part of having much better behavior is that I've seen only three or four crashes, and I've not yet noticed a pattern -- so I can't say what's needed to reproduce them.

Fortunately, I _was_ able to collect some problem reports, and they are attached.

I've marked this issue as "Critical" rather than "Blocker" because, again, the crashes aren't nearly as frequent.  You may want to change that marking.

@mbasaralusrinivasa asked me to create this issue.
fields.summary: SourceTree suffers from random crashes

fields.description:
Repro Steps:
# Open git with several commits
# Create two or more branches on commit C name b1 and b2
# Create branch on commit A name my
# Checkout branch my
# Select commit C, right click it and select Merge

Expected Result:
The merge dialog will appear

Actual Result:
Nothing happens

{code:title=Branches structure|borderStyle=solid}
*  C [b1, b2]
|
*  B
|
*  A [my]
{code}
fields.summary: Merging to commit that has several branches on it does not work

fields.description:
In the commit tree of the log/history tab, the tags are truncated when containing a parenthesis.
Ex:
'test(1000)' is displayed in the commit tree as 'test'
The tag is well displayed on the left side of SourceTree (File status, branches, tags, remotes)

SRCTREEWIN-910
fields.summary: Tag with parenthesis is truncated

fields.description:
Clone repository window only supports Source URL paste. 

There is no browse for local path button. That makes cloning local repositories harder. 

You either have to type in local repo path in Source URL field, or as workaround browse to local repo using Destination Path browse button and then copy-paste that path to Source URL.
fields.summary: Clone repository - cannot browse to clone local repo

Please refer to multiple users including myself having stability issues with 2.0.5.6.

https://answers.atlassian.com/questions/32516436/comments/32522057

Thank you

fields.description:
SourceTree crashed few times with following steps

1. New Repository 
2. Clone From URL
3. Cloning is even easier if you setup a remote account -> click on remote account -> crash

However, after several crashes it opened list of Bitbucket remote repositories

fields.description:
I updated sourceTree for mac to version 2.0.5.6 and the program crashed every time i opened it after about 3 seconds. I did not do press any button or anything else, it just crashed out of the nothing.

I now went back to version 2.0.3 and it works again..

Easy way to restore default view arrangement

fields.description: It would be nice if we have possibility to search in past commits descriptions. Sometimes I remember commit copy but not where it was in storyline.
fields.summary: Searching in git commit descriptions

fields.description: I just got an update to 2.0.5.6 (which curiously is listed as unreleased version here in Jira), and now SourceTree dies with a segmentation fault a couple of seconds after I start it. It isn't triggered by any action on my part, just starting it and waiting two seconds is enough for it to crash. I tried closing all my repo windows, didn't affect the crash.
fields.summary: SourceTree crashes a couple of seconds after start

fields.description:
Bitbucket recently enabled two-factor authentication. In order to adopt this, SSH keys must be set up to allow clients like Sourcetree to access repos, and clients must be written to support this authentication method.

Sourcetree has implemented this just fine for accessing and updating repos, but the built-in Bitbucket repo browser does not seem to support SSH login, even though it claims to. This is the case in the Windows and Mac versions.

Repro steps (on mac):

1. Window menu -> Show remote hosted repositories
2. gear icon -> settings
3. Add account. Choose host bitbucket, enter username and password, choose protocol SSH.
4. Save and refresh.

Expected behavior:

Repos available on bitbucket for the login are visible in the list

Actual behavior:

Login error.

Additional notes:

It is odd that there is still a password field in the auth dialog when the SSH protocol is chosen. We would expect the password field to disappear when the SSH protocol is chosen, since a password is not needed for SSH connection (and isn't usable when 2fa is turned on for the BitBucket user).
fields.summary: Sourcetree does not currently support Bitbucket 2fa implementation.

fields.description: SourceTree remembers window size personally for each git repository, which causes an usability issue - it would be good if it can apply current window size attributes to all new windows.
fields.summary: Resizing one repository window should apply all other new repository windows with that same size as well

fields.description:
As of now, this only involves repository bookmarks in SourceTree for Mac that are within a group tab.

Steps to reproduce:

1. Move a local repository folder to a new location in the machine.
2. Open repository through SourceTree bookmark; when repository missing message pops up, choose "Change Folder" and change the location.
3. Here's where the bug occurs - according to the customer that reported this:

{quote}
sometimes after changing the folder, the warning disappears.

sometimes the warning doesn't disappear but upon relaunching the warning goes away and the folder change works as expected.

sometimes when the warning doesn't disappear clicking on the bookmark again does nothing; if the repo window is already open then it is not brought into focus and made the topmost window.

sometimes when the warning doesn't disappear, clicking on the bookmark again brings up the change folder dialog again.

the behaviour seems to be exacerbated by opening another bookmark before the warning of the previously opened and reconnected bookmark has disappeared.
{quote}
fields.summary: Changing folder of a bookmark is really buggy when its local repository folder is moved

fields.description:
IDEA is a very good (and free) merge tool. Here's how to launch it:
https://www.jetbrains.com/idea/help/running-intellij-idea-as-a-diff-or-merge-command-line-tool.html

But sourcetree setup is tricky:
http://stackoverflow.com/questions/14774053/intellij-diff-tool-in-sourcetree

Please, add a default option, like KDiff3 and others.
fields.summary: Use JetBrains IDEA as diff/merge tool

fields.description: Source tree crashes immediately after clicking on the "remote" tab. See trace attached
fields.summary: Crash after clicking on the "remote" tab

fields.description:
All too often, we get a bad merge because of someone (usually less experienced user) discarding files from a merge conflict, not realising they were in a merge conflict. Then we have a bad merge in our history that takes some fiddling about with to rectify.

Suggestion:
When you're in a special state (merge conflict or rebase), it should be blindingly obvious that you're not in a normal state, my suggestion would be to tint the entire UI yellow or red, so that it's obvious to the less experienced user that they are in a different situation. Certainly doing something like reset --hard should come with extremely strong warnings.
fields.summary: Merge conflict state should be more obvious

fields.description:
When using SourceTree with large number of repositories, it becomes very inconvenient to have all of them in single list.
To solve that issue, I think SourceTree needs user-defined groups/grouping in Repository Browser.
fields.summary: Groups in Repository Browser

fields.description: Suggestion to flip merge/branch icon vertically as It is quite confusing for newbies to find out the meaning.
fields.summary: Why is the merge icon left-oriented, while we merge from right?

fields.description: If you use the "flat list" in the commit view, only one file with changes is shown. Until the last version of SourceTree you could see all changed files listed as expected. If you use the "tree view" the files are listed like they were in the flat view before (but this is not a tree view).
fields.summary: Only one file shown in flat list

fields.description: I work in Git Flow mode (embedded mode in Sourcetree) and after creating of regular feature branch I saw that in the list of repositories I cannot see my repo name and feature branch name.
fields.summary: Repositories list, stretched and empty repo title

fields.description: If you have a working copy with current changes and resize the sidebar enough, the number of files changed label on the right ends up cutting off the text slightly.
fields.summary: Working Copy Number of Changes cuts off text

fields.description: If you select a repository or multiple repositories in the repo browser, right clicking New Group, should actually group them automatically. Like the finder does when selecting a bunch of files and selecting new folder with selection,
fields.summary: In the Local Repository Browser, right clicking New Group does not automatically group repos
